page.title: 03LLANDYSUL CHURCH
page.content: The Norman church in the village is dedicated to St.Tysul(462-544) and gives Llandysul its name = The Church of Tysul. The ancient altar icorporated in the present stone altar must be regarded as an unique relic of Early Christianity. The Velvor stone, inscribed VELVOR FILIA BROHO in Roman letters, is set in the wall and dates back fourteen centuries. The tower is of the Norman period, and shows four periods of construction. The battlements are an ornamental finish. The four corners are gargoyles forming water spouts. The walled-up window in the south wall is one of the oldest pieces of stone eccclesiastical arch- itecture in Wales. Figure-heads are found on all the windows; the capitals of the northern doorway are formed of the heads of a knight and a lady.
